Description: Body sherd of large Corinthian black-figured pottery alabastron; exterior, from top: black area with added red line; narrow reserved band; tall band of double-incised scales with large dots in added red and small dots in added white at centre of alternate rows of scales.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd possibly belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1924, 1201,1219. The sherd is attributed, by Payne, to the Scale Pattern Group.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 37, pl. XVIII, no. 46)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 25, note 6)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 64, no. A41)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.280) (phase 3)
